awd_titl_txt: Physics at the Frontier: Colliders to Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Will Kinney, Dejan Stojkovic, Doreen Wackeroth, and Ciaran Williams at the University at Buffalo, The State University of New York. 

The PIs will conduct a wide-ranging research program which aims to provide answers to key open questions at the frontier of particle physics, cosmology, and gravity research.  Research topics to be investigated span a large range, including the physics of cosmological inflation, the physics of black holes, the physics of Dark Energy (which is believed responsible for driving accelerated cosmological expansion), the properties of the Higgs boson, and studies of the theory that underlies the strong interaction and its effects at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and at future accelerators.  This research aligns with NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and advance the national welfare by performing research aimed at extending our understanding of the origin and structure of the universe, and the properties of fundamental particles and fields.  As part of this research, Professors Kinney, Stojkovic, Wackeroth, and Williams will involve graduate students and postdocs in their research and thereby provide training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. The PIs will also continue to conduct public outreach, including public lectures, planetarium shows, interactions with the press and other media, and the Science & Art Cabaret series, now in its twelfth season.  

More technically, Kinney's research will involve investigation of so-called "swampland" criteria in the context of early-universe physics.   He will also seek to constrain the physics of inflation with new observations of the Cosmic Microwave Background and Large-scale Structure, and (in collaboration with Stojkovic) explore possible resolutions of the Hubble tension.  Stojkovic will continue the development of a comprehensive event generator BlackMax which is currently used by the LHC collaborations in searches for exotic physics. In collaboration with Wackeroth and Williams, Stojkovic will also explore the gamma-ray and neutrino signatures of bubble production associated with false Higgs-vacuum decay and other cosmological phase transitions. Stojkovic will also study the imposition of observational strong-lensing constraints on a wide class of modified-gravity models.  Wackeroth will focus on mixed QCD-Electroweak (EW) corrections to W and Z boson production, which is relevant for a high-precision W-mass measurement.  Wackeroth will also provide improved predictions for SM processes which will allow for new tests of non-standard interactions of the top quark and the quartic electroweak self-interactions.  Williams will calculate NNLO corrections to Higgs production in association with a b-jet, and will also calculate the mixed QCD-EW terms for the H-to-bb process and use the results to constrain the ultimate precision for the bottom-quark Yukawa coupling which may be reached at future lepton colliders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research completed under this grant focused on research by four faculty in the University at Buffalo (UB)  High-Energy Physics and Cosmology group: Kinney, Stojkovic, Wackeroth, and Williams. High energy physics is aimed at understanding our universe from the smallest to the largest scales: The questions being asked are profound, ambitious and difficult. Answering them may take decades or more. Nonetheless, at least some appear to be within our reach. The nature of the problems treated is such that their resolution will inevitably involve different concepts from particle physics, gravitation and cosmology. Accordingly, the 2021 series of Snowmass workshops has identified a set of broadly defined ``Frontiers'' as priorities for future research.  The research proposed here is closely focused on two of these priorities, the Energy and Cosmic Frontiers, and collaborative efforts addressed the many regions of overlap between these broad categories. 

Among the questions addressed are:

How did the universe begin?

Why is the universe accelerating?

What is  dark matter?

Are there hints of physics beyond the Standard Model?

Kinney's research focused primarily on the interface between early universe cosmology and fundamental theories of particle physics. A major focus of research under this grant was the question of ``geodesic completeness'', which addresses the question of whether a cosmological solution can be extended infinitely into the past. A major result was showing that recently proposed cyclic models of cosmology are in fact geodesically incomplete, meaning that they cannot be extended infinitely into the past.  A second research focus was on the ``constant roll'' inflation scenario, which was pioneered in earlier work by Kinney, who studied the simplest example of ultra-slow roll inflation. These models are significant especially because they are a mechanism for generating primordial black holes in the early universe, which are a candidate for the (as yet unidentified) cosmological dark matter.

Stojkovic's research spanned a wide variety of topics on the interface of cosmology, gravity and particle physics. He continued with maintaining and updating the event generator BlackMax, so that the members of the ATLAS, CMS and MOEDAL collaborations, as well as other interested users can use the generator smoothly as other supporting and complementary software keeps evolving. He also studied classical and quantum aspects of black hole physics like the explicit construction of Penrose diagrams for various interesting scenarios (like black hole to white hole and black hole to de Sitter space transitions), the effect of the black hole superradiance, and analytic solutions for the Kerr black hole perturbations with immediate applications for gravitational wave physics. Finally, he showed that variations in quasars’ light curves can be used in principle to promote quasars into standard candles thus probing the history of the universe previously inaccessible to SNe. In this context, it appears that quasars point out that significant modifications of the Lambda CDM model might be warranted.

Wackeroth's research focus is concerned with the interpretation of experimental observations to gain insight in the fundamental interactions of elementary particles. Since the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the goal is now to precisely determine the properties of this new particle and to search for signals of Beyond-the-SM physics. BSM physics may manifest itself in minute deviations in the comparison of precision data and their SM predictions due to the presence of BSM particles in quantum-loop corrections. It is therefore of the utmost importance that SM predictions are under superb theoretical control which requires the calculation of higher order corrections in perturbation theory. This grant supported calculations of these corrections in QCD and Electroweak theory for key processes at the LHC, such as hadronic Z+b-jet production, hadronic top-pair production in association with leptons, and triple gauge-boson production.

Williams’ interests aim to provide accurate theoretical calculations for thw physics program at the LHC. The machine is operating to such high standards that in order match the precision of the experimental data, the theoretical calculations have to be extended beyond previous results. Williams joined this award in the final year and completed three projects. Firstly, Williams, together with a UB graduate student, completed the calculation of a series of Electroweak  two-loop master integrals for gluon fusion to two photons. This process is of interest at the HL-LHC as a means to constrain the Higgs width. Secondly, Williams, completed new predictions for the event shapes of a Higgs boson decaying to four hadrons at NLO. Finally Williams, together with a UB graduate student, completed the NNLO calculation of a pseudo-scalar Higgs boson in association with a jet and studied the phenomenology at the LHC. 

 

Broader impacts included research training for both graduate and undergraduate students, conference presentations and public talks. Kinney published a popular book, ``An Infinity of Worlds: Cosmic Inflation and the Beginning of the Universe'', with MIT Press in 2022.
